A new API Integration Flow Pipeline API ‚Äì Restart Job Log has been introduced in the latest package version. This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of Restart Job Logs, provided that the RestartJobLog parameter of the Job Profile is set to either "attach" or "persist".

The following queries are supported:

  • Retrieve the restart job log for a specific Restart Job instance by supplying either the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.
  • Query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs based on selection criteria, in order to obtain the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.

For further details, see the updated Configuration Guide included in the package.

entry.title: Test Automation Solution for PO7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration
entry.content:
Test Automation Solution for PO 7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration

Enterprises are transitioning away from legacy SAP Process Orchestration (PO) towards SAP Integration Suite as PO approaches end of life. While this migration promises better scalability and integration capabilities, it also brings a significant challenge of ensuring data consistency and integrity throughout the process without disrupting business users.

In any migration project, testing can consume around 40% to 50% of the overall effort if done manually. Manual testing is time-consuming and prone to human error. Complex interfaces, multiple test cases, and large volumes of data drives up the time and cost of testing. Thoroughly validating that the new environment behaves as expected is critical to a successful transition. This is where automated testing solutions comes into play, simplifying and accelerating the validation of migrated interfaces.

 We have built a test tool to extract, compare, and validate payloads between your legacy PO system and SAP Integration Suite. This tool simplifies and automates testing of migrated iFlows, making your transition smoother, faster, and more reliable.

Key Features of Our Test Automation Tool

  • Automates payload extraction from SAP PO 7.5: Extracts input and output messages from your existing PO environment. It establishes connectivity with the PO System and pulls the payload for testing.
  • Validates test cases directly against migrated flows in Cloud Integration : Run test scenarios on the target platform(SAP Integration Suite) to verify correctness of migration.
  • Compares output payloads across systems: Detect any mismatches or errors.
  • Supports various testing approach: Whether testing single or multiple interfaces, Our tool adapts to project needs. It supports regression testing.
  • Generates detailed, downloadable test reports: Gain visibility into test results with comprehensive  reports.
  • Alerts via mails in case of failures: Immediate notifications enable quick corrective actions.
  • Supports standard adapters.
  • Monitoring through quality management and governance dashboard.

Whether you are migrating a few interfaces or hundreds, test tool brings efficiency, visibility, and reliability to your testing process saving both time and cost.

Integrating our test automation tool into your migration strategy will help with:

  • Faster testing cycles that reduce the overall migration timeline.
  • Improved reliability with consistent, repeatable automated test runs.
  • Greater visibility into testing outcomes through detailed reports.
  • Enhanced confidence that migrated interfaces behave exactly as expected.
  • Scalability to handle migrations involving just a few interfaces or hundreds.

Ready to accelerate your PO migration testing during migration? Reach out to learn how our tool can simplify your migration from PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite and save time, reduce costs, and ensure a smooth migration.

entry.title: Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance
entry.content:
Migration Journey Overview: From Assessment to Tooling

Migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite represents a significant milestone in your organization‚Äôs cloud transformation journey. This master blog serves as a central hub for comprehensive information and guidance related to the Migration Tool and the broader migration process. It provides links to detailed blogs, documentation, and best practices to help you successfully plan and execute your migration to SAP Integration Suite.

Before beginning any migration activity, it‚Äôs crucial to start with the Migration Assessment - a key capability of the SAP Integration Suite. The assessment analyses your on-premises landscape, including existing integration configurations, mappings, custom adapters, and dependent objects. It provides detailed insights and a comprehensive overview indicating which scenarios can be migrated as-is, which ones require optimization, and which may need to be redesigned or modernized. This step establishes a clear, data-driven foundation for a successful and efficient migration journey.

Once your Migration Assessment is complete, the next big step is moving your integration content to the cloud - and that‚Äôs where the Migration Tool comes into play!

The Migration Tool, built into SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Cloud Integration capability, helps you bring your existing integration scenarios from SAP Process Orchestration to the cloud with ease. Think of it as your Guided workflow for migration - it identifies what can be moved, converts integration artifacts into their cloud-ready counterparts, and helps you streamline the entire process with minimal manual effort.

Migration Tool ‚Äì Offerings and Supported Components

The Migration Tool comes packed with a set of features to make your move from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite smoother and faster. Here‚Äôs an overview of the key components it supports and automates.

Connectivity to On-Premise Systems: Choose the appropriate connection setup for securely linking your on-premise landscape with the SAP Integration Suite. For detailed configuration options, see Configuring Connectivity to an SAP Process Orchestration System

Object Types: The tool supports migration of integration artifacts such as Integrated Configurations, which define how messages are processed within the Java-only runtime of SAP Process Orchestration systems.

It also supports Receiver Determination, which is available in SAP Process Integration dual-stack installations (from release 7.5 onwards) where message processing takes place on both ABAP and Java stacks.

 

Patterns: The Migration Tool supports a variety of integration patterns to help you transition your existing scenarios to cloud-ready designs. These patterns provide flexibility for different integration needs - whether it‚Äôs point-to-point communication, content-based routing, or complex orchestration flows.

For the complete list of supported patterns, refer to the Migration Patterns

Migration Approaches: The Migration Tool offers two approaches - Standard Approach and Pipeline Approach to help you move your integration scenarios efficiently to the cloud. For more details, see Pipeline Concept

 

Communication Channels: The Migration Tool helps move your existing communication channels to the cloud, making sure your integration endpoints and related settings are mapped correctly. A few exceptions may apply, so some channels might need minor adjustments after migration. For more details, see Standard Adapter Migration.

Adapter Module Support: The tool automatically migrates PGP encryption and decryption modules to cloud-compatible configurations. Additional adapter modules are provided through the community package and can be leveraged as needed. The following list provides an overview: Adapter Modules

Decoupling and Ordered Message Processing with JMS Queues: The Migration Tool supports JMS queue configurations to enable decoupled communication between senders and receivers. In SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration, internal JMS Adapter help separate asynchronous message processing from the sender, allowing messages to be handled independently and reliably.

To ensure messages are processed in the correct order - EOIO, the Access Type should be set to Exclusive, which ensures that only one consumer/worker processes messages from the queue at a time.

Note: This configuration is not applied automatically by the Migration Tool and must be set manually.

Idempotent at Receiver: The tool also provides idempotent message handling at the receiver side. This means it helps prevent duplicate message processing, ensuring that each message is delivered and processed only once - an essential feature for maintaining data consistency.

Reusing Artifacts for Efficient Migration: The Migration Tool provides options for users to reuse existing standalone artifacts - message mappings and function libraries, to their migrated scenarios. This flexibility allows message mappings and other artifacts to be reused across multiple integration scenarios, reducing redundancy and speeding up the migration process.

Example: Enable Reusable Artifacts

 

Migration Summary: After the migration, a detailed summary report provides an overview of all successfully migrated Integration Flow Configurations and their related objects in the cloud. If any object could not be migrated, this information is clearly highlighted in the summary, helping you identify follow-up actions easily.

The Migration Tool does offer a downloadable Summary Report that captures essential migration details - including the on-premise system details, integration patterns used, chosen migration approach, and other key information related to each migrated object, which you can review later if required.

Note: If you‚Äôd like to select an alternative runtime profile instead of the default Cloud Integration, you can manually set it in the Integration Runtime configuration after the successful migration of the Integration Flow.

Error Logs: When the Migration Tool cannot migrate to certain integration scenarios, it generates a detailed error log summary. This log provides insights into the specific issues encountered, helping you understand what went wrong and take corrective actions.

Hint: The error log is available to download as a .csv file. You can import it in Excel and use a delimiter as Comma (,) to transform the data, to review and analyse the migration errors effectively check columns ‚ÄòStatus‚Äô and ‚ÄòMessage‚Äô.

 

For detailed, step-by-step instructions on using the Migration Tool, refer to the official tutorial: Use the Migration Tooling

 

Known Limitations of the Migration Tool

While the Migration Tool covers a wide range of integration scenarios, there are some known gaps and limitations. For the most up-to-date information, refer to Known Limitations of Migration Tooling 

Disclaimer: The list of gaps and limitations may shorten as SAP expands coverage and implements features on its roadmap

 

Next in the Series

Stay tuned for the upcoming posts where we will dive deeper into specific migration scenarios, tips, and best practices to help you get the most out of SAP Integration Suite.

Published:

‚úÖ Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite

‚úÖ Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite 

 

Up Next:

‚û°Ô∏èMigrating Content-Based Routing Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite

 

 

References - SAP Documentation and Blogs:

Migration Guide for SAP Process Orchestration

Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite

Assessment Blog: How to use the Migration Assessment Application to get ready to migrate your SAP Process Orchestration Scenarios?

Migration Tool: Migration tool in Cloud Integration Capability of SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Introduction:

Managing API rate restrictions or avoiding backend system overloads are common problems in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). When an API receives too many requests in a short period of time, some may reject them, while others may experience significant slowdowns.

In this post, I will demonstrate how to create a dynamic delay mechanism in CPI using Groovy Script, where the sleep duration varies according to request count(header value).

Problem Statement:

  • Rate-limiting is often necessary for backend or API services.
  • Standard CPI configuration does not offer a built-in dynamic sleep/throttle feature.
  • When the load increases, developers need a lightweight way to decrease request speeds.

Solution Approach:

We can use a Groovy Script in CPI to:

1 .Read a custom header (SAP_ApplicationID in this case).

2. Transform it into an integer request count.

3. Implement adaptive delay logic with different thresholds.

Proceed with processing after the determined sleep duration.

//Groovy script
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
 
def Message processData(Message message) {
 
    def body = message.getBody();
 
    // Read SAP_ApplicationID
    def headerValue = message.getHeader("SAP_ApplicationID", String.class);
    def requestCount = 0;
 
    if (headerValue != null) {
        try {
            requestCount = headerValue.toInteger();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            requestCount = 0; // Default if not a number
        }
    }
 
    // Determine sleep time 
    def sleepTime = 0;
    if (requestCount >= 3500) {
        sleepTime = 1500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 2000) {
        sleepTime = 1000;
    } else if (requestCount >= 1000) {
        sleepTime = 500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 500) {
        sleepTime = 200;
    } else if (requestCount < 500) {
        sleepTime = 100;
    }
 
    // Apply sleep delay
    if (sleepTime > 0) {
        sleep(sleepTime);
    }
 
    message.setBody(body);
    return message;
}

How it works :

Step 1: Get SAP_ApplicationID from headers.

Step 2: Convert it into an integer(requestCount).

Step 3: Decide sleep time dynamically:

  •  ‚â• 3500 - 1500 ms
  •  ‚â• 2000 - 1000 ms 
  •  ‚â• 1000 - 500 ms
  •  ‚â• 500 - 200 ms
  •  < 500 - 100 ms

Step 4: Sleep for calculated time.

Step 5: Pass the original message forward.

Use cases:

1. For high-frequency situations, API rate restriction with shorter delays works perfectly.

2. Backend overload protection with millisecond-level throttling.

3. Testing integrations under various load conditions.

Conclusion:

This Groovy script provides a simple but effective way to dynamically throttle requests in SAP CPI based on header values. By introducing adaptive delays, you can protect backend systems, comply with API rate limits, and simulate controlled load behaviour.

entry.title: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will focus on the Point-to-Point (P2P) Asynchronous pattern, which is one of the most common and fundamental integration scenarios.

 

Objective

The goal of this blog is to explain how the Migration Tool supports P2P asynchronous integrations, including:

  • Key configuration options and technical considerations
  • Best practices to ensure reliable and decoupled communication
  • How to implement JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing effectively

 

Understanding the Point-to-Point Asynchronous Pattern

In a Point-to-Point (P2P) asynchronous integration, a message is sent from a sender to a receiver without a response message. This pattern promotes decoupling between systems, improves reliability, and allows retry mechanisms to ensure delivery in case you are using JMS queues. By default, the Migration Tool will enable JMS queues during migration.

If there are constraints on the limit of available JMS queues, the tool also supports direct communication without JMS, though this reduces decoupling and resilience. If you are migrating a high number of asynchronous interfaces, SAP recommends using the pipeline approach, which will not be covered in this blog. You can find more information in Pipeline Concept and  Migration Tooling now supporting migration via the pipeline approach.

 

Migration Tool Support for P2P Asynchronous Scenarios using Standard Approach

The Migration Tool automates most of the effort by generating a ready-to-use Integration Flow (iFlow) and the corresponding configuration objects in SAP Cloud Integration.

Depending on your settings, the tool can generate Integration Flows that:

1. Decouple with JMS Queue: Use JMS queues for decoupling between sender and receiver systems (only shown for Asynchronous interfaces):

When you select this option, the Migration Tool creates two Integration Processes within the generated iFlow:

  • Inbound Process
    • Receives the message from the migrated Sender Component and Communication Channel
    • Forwards the message to the JMS queue
  • Outbound Process
    • Reads the message from the JMS queue
    • Performs any required processing (e.g., message mapping, data transformation)

Delivers the message to the receiver system

Please note that you need to maintain the name of the JMS queue post-migration using the already created external parameters:

2. Idempotent Process at the Receiver Side: Use the idempotent process call if you want to make sure that the message will be delivered exactly once to the target system:

When you select this option, the generated iFlow will include an Idempotent Process Call. This mechanism ensures that a message is delivered exactly once to the receiver system, avoiding duplicate postings.

The API call at the receiver system is wrapped then into this local integration process.

There are receiver adapters that do supports idempotency such as SOAP RM, XI and IDoc. In these cases, it‚Äôs preferable that you don‚Äôt use the Idempotent option on Migration Tool and choose to handle it directly in the adapter. You can find more information in Special Use Cases: SAP RM vs XI vs IDoc.

 

Post-Migration Activities and Special Scenarios

While the Migration Tool significantly accelerates the transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, a few manual fine-tuning steps are typically required.

Generic Post-Migration Steps

After migrating a P2P Asynchronous interface:

  1. Review and update external parameters for sender and receiver connectivity.
  2. Define the JMS queue name to be used in both Integration Processes (in case checkbox is marked during wizard). This can be done in the external parameters‚Äô configuration view.
  3. Update
  4. Review if you want to change the value of the header SAP_Sender according to the naming convention that will be adopted on SAP Integration Suite.

Manual Activities Depending on Integration Scenario

You can also find below few examples of manual activities post-migration that needs to be performed depending on the content of your integration scenario:

  1. Functions like RFC Lookup or JDBC Lookup on Graphical Message Mapping are not automatically converted. Replace them with equivalent Integration Suite adapters or externalized APIs. Tutorials are available for JDBC lookups and RFC lookups.
  2. If your interface is using any custom code (e.g., UDF, Function Library, Java Mapping) or XSLT that have additional dependencies, Therefore, you need to export them from SAP Process Orchestration and import into your Integration Flow
  3. If your interface is using a fault message handling, this won‚Äôt be migrated using the Migration Tool. Therefore, you need to import the mapping using the standalone functionality and add an exception handling subprocess into the migrated iFlow

Please refer to the Known Limitations of Migration Tooling for additional insights into cases that may require manual adjustments after migration. we will explore specific topics in more depth, such as XSLT transformation differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite, custom code migration, fault message handling, and other advanced migration scenarios.

 

Async-Sync Bridge Support

The Point-to-Point Asynchronous pattern also covers scenarios using an Async-Sync bridge.

In SAP Process Orchestration, an asynchronous interface is converted into synchronous using the RequestResponseBean module, enabling a response message to be sent back to the sender asynchronously using a second interface object.

The Migration Tool can migrate this Async-Sync bridge scenario as well, ensuring that both asynchronous and synchronous steps are merged into a single iFlow.

Please note that the Sync-Async bridge scenario (the opposite from the above), is not supported as of today.

 

Conclusion

In this first blog of the blog series, we explored how to migrate Point-to-Point Asynchronous scenarios and how the Migration Tool simplifies this process by leveraging JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing. These capabilities help ensure reliable, scalable, and fault-tolerant communication between systems.

entry.title: How to connect SAP PO running over netweaver 7.50 with OpenText XML Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's digital landscape, enterprises rely heavily on seamless integration between platforms to maintain agility, optimize operations, and enhance digital transformation initiatives. SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) is a comprehensive integration software that enables the synchronization of processes and data across numerous SAP and non-SAP applications. One such integration possibility involves connecting SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API to facilitate efficient document management capabilities.

OpenText is a leading enterprise information management company known for its robust solutions, including its SOAP API which provides functionalities for document management. Integrating SAP PO with OpenText's SOAP API allows organizations to achieve a streamlined connection between their business processes and their document management systems, thereby enhancing access to vital information and documents.

Before embarking on this integration journey, several key considerations must be addressed, including authentication mechanisms, message format mapping, and error handling. Given that SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) relies on XML-based messaging protocols, mastering these elements is critical for a successful and secure integration. This article will guide you through the essential steps for establish a secure connection to OpenText's SOAP API and offer insights into how to authenticate users and manage documents effectively.

Goal

The goal of this article is to guide enterprises on connecting a legacy system to OpenText using SAP PO, and to generate a single endpoint that encapsulates multiple requests to different services exposed by OpenText. By achieving this, organizations can streamline their document management processes, reduce complexity, and enhance the efficiency of their operations.

 

The first step in order to achieve the integration of both systems will be to Establishing a secure and reliable connection between SAP PO and OpenText's SOAP API requires robust authentication mechanisms.

In this case we will delve into the basic authentication. Understanding this methodology is crucial for safeguarding your data and ensuring authorized access only.

Once authenticated, the core of the integration lies in the consumption of document management features offered by the OpenText SOAP API. This section offers a step-by-step guide on how to configure SAP PO to interact with OpenText's document management functionalities.

To simplify, the basic architecture will be structured this way.

A single interface is presented to the legacy system, which is then divided within SAP PI to engage multiple interfaces based on a custom tag referred to as method.

Step 1.

Generate a single data type with a common structure for the services that will be consolidated on one.

The following Data Type will be used as the request

And this Data Type will be used for the response

Transformation process involve several use of graphical mapping and XSLT transformations in order to achieve the goal to get a single entry point for all the exposed services, with the graphical mappings allowing to include transformations and validations in order to detect the data type received 

Step 2 

Define the graphical message mappings for request and response, one for each inbound service interface defined.

Step 3

At the response graphical mapping, add custom java functions in order to identify and set the data type of the values that are returning, the custom functions must to be embedded inside the mapping and be called as custom functions.

This custom function receive 5 entry parameters that are returned by the opentext get node method, evaluate the data type of the value and return a single text with the description of the type, the goal of this is reduce the complexity of the logic at the legacy system.

Here is the Java code of the custom function

 

at also another custom function was developed to validate the data type of any value returned at the Values tag

Step 4

Build the XSLT transformations in order to adapt the structure to the opentext services, this will add the corresponding namespaces, eliminate non necessary tags and generate the parents when will be need it.

Step 5.

Build the operation mapping that will be in charge of call sequentially the graphical message mapping and the XSLT transformations, this operation mapping will have one step for request and another for response considering the process defined as Synchronous.

Request side will at first call the graphical mapping and at second will use the XSLT transformation

The response side will call the XSLT transformation that will adapt the structure, then add the namespace and at last use the graphical mapping where the custom java functions are located

Once all the steps are done and the iFlow is created and deployed the service could be tested using SOAP UI.

 

Conclusion

This approach allow to generate a single endpoint to consume some specific methods of the Opentext implementation, allowing to get an homogeneous structure at response, but will require some work if new methods will be implemented, at also the architecture could be considered slightly coupled since maintenance could be required as well but not frequently.

The current architecture could face several challenges to be migrated to SAP Integration Suite running over BTP

entry.title: Partnering for Progress: Accelerate Your Move to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
When I first started working with SAP‚Äôs Migration Factory program, I quickly realized just how big of a shift many organizations were facing.
For years, SAP Process Integration (PI) and SAP Process Orchestration (PO) have been the backbone of countless businesses‚Äô integration landscapes. But with mainstream maintenance ending in 2027, the question everyone‚Äôs asking is: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next?‚Äù

And the answer is clear ‚Äî SAP Integration Suite on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It‚Äôs modern, scalable, and built to meet the needs of today‚Äôs connected, cloud-first world. But let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî migration isn‚Äôt just about technology. It‚Äôs about people, collaboration, and having the right partners by your side.

That‚Äôs where Migration Factory 2.0 comes in.

Building a Stronger Ecosystem ‚Äî Together

What excites me most about Migration Factory 2.0 is that it‚Äôs not just a framework ‚Äî it‚Äôs a movement.
We‚Äôre bringing together SAP and our partners under one unified goal: to help customers modernize with speed, confidence, and shared expertise.

Through this program, partners get the enablement and resources they need to deliver migrations effectively, and customers get access to a trusted ecosystem that‚Äôs been trained, certified, and supported directly by SAP.

It‚Äôs truly a ‚Äúwin-win-win‚Äù ‚Äî for SAP, our partners, and most importantly, our customers.

Behind the Program: Enablement, Execution, and Engagement

At its core, Migration Factory 2.0 is built on three simple but powerful pillars:

  • Enablement: We equip partners with the latest training, certifications, and migration tooling ‚Äî including our Integration Suite Black Belt 2.0 program.

  • Execution: We support them with proven methodologies, automation frameworks, and best practices developed alongside SAP experts.

  • Engagement: We celebrate their success through co-marketing, events, and storytelling opportunities that amplify their impact across the SAP ecosystem.

Every one of these pillars is about empowering collaboration ‚Äî because success in integration isn‚Äôt achieved in isolation.

Why Partners Are the Game Changers

Working closely with our partners, I‚Äôve seen firsthand the dedication, innovation, and creativity they bring to every customer engagement.
Migration Factory 2.0 gives them more than just visibility ‚Äî it gives them a platform to shine.

Through the program, partners can:

  • Earn SAP‚Äôs Partner Badge for SAP PO/SAP Integration Suite Modernization

  • Be featured on our Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com

  • Participate in co-marketing campaigns, webinars, and video series like Integration Situation

  • Receive qualified migration assessments from SAP

  • Connect with other partners and SAP experts through enablement sessions and community collaboration spaces

It‚Äôs inspiring to see how quickly our partner community has embraced this journey ‚Äî not just as a business opportunity, but as a shared mission to help customers move forward.

Helping Customers Choose the Right Partner

For customers, we‚Äôve made it easy to find the right expertise through the Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com.
Each partner listed has been enabled through SAP‚Äôs framework and offers migration assessments, readiness checks, or implementation services tailored to customer needs.

Whether you‚Äôre in Europe, Asia, or North America ‚Äî you can now connect directly with a partner who understands your regional and industry-specific challenges.

My Favorite Part: The Collaboration

One of my favorite things about being part of this initiative is watching new partnerships form ‚Äî partners collaborating with each other, learning from SAP experts, and even co-creating new migration approaches together.
It‚Äôs a reminder that technology may power transformation, but people make it happen.

Every week, I see stories from partners who have taken what they learned from Migration Factory enablement sessions and turned it into real customer impact. That‚Äôs what keeps me passionate about this program ‚Äî it‚Äôs not theory, it‚Äôs transformation in action.

Let‚Äôs Move Forward ‚Äî Together

If you‚Äôre a partner, now‚Äôs the time to get involved.
Join the Migration Factory 2.0 program, earn your certifications, and showcase your success stories to the global SAP community.

If you‚Äôre a customer, explore the Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com to connect with certified experts who can help you plan your move from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite.

The future of integration is here ‚Äî and it‚Äôs collaborative, connected, and cloud-driven.
Together, we‚Äôre accelerating integration modernization ‚Äî one connection at a time.

entry.title: Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will explore the migration process of XSLT mappings.   

While SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration supports XSLT mappings, you may encounter subtle yet impactful differences when migrating XSLT-based mappings from SAP Process Orchestration (PO). This post outlines the main variations between both environments, explains typical runtime issues, and provides practical guidance for smooth adaptation.

 

XSLT Processor Differences 

The XSLT processor behind Cloud Integration is Saxon EE 9.9.1.6 (as of November 2025 ‚Äì see this Blog for details on verifying the processor version) while SAP Process Orchestration next to its default allowed the import and use of other processors. 

While these differences should not usually cause major compatibility problems, certain manual adjustments after the tool-assisted migration might be required to deploy or execute mappings successfully. In particular, there are variations in how standard XSLT functions handle data types, how Java classes are used within XSLT code and how other stylesheets are included. 

 

Data Type Handling in XSLT Functions 

SAP Process Orchestration tends to be more lenient regarding data type usage in standard XSLT functions. Cloud Integration, on the other hand, applies stricter type validation during compilation and runtime. 

Example 1: Using xsl:sort with Data Types 

The xsl:sort function sorts data based on specified criteria: 

<xsl:sort select="data" data-type="text"/> 

The allowed data types for this function are "text" and "number". On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:sort select="DATES" order="ascending" data-type="xsd:Date"/> 

However, in Cloud Integration this causes a runtime error: 

Adjusting the data-type accordingly to text or number solves this issue. However, one needs to pay attention to the effects this might have on the format and thus the rest of the stylesheet execution. 

 

Example 2: Using format-number() with non-numeric inputs 

On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(substring(data, 0, 3), '0.00')"/> 

In Cloud Integration, this causes a compilation error during runtime: 

The issue arises because format-number() requires a numeric input, while substring() returns a string. 
To resolve this, explicitly convert the substring to a number: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(number(substring(data, 0, 3)), '0.00')"/> 

Please note that if a global number format is defined, this conversion might affect the formatting of the substring according to that global setting. 

 

Using Java Classes in XSLT 

XSLT mappings sometimes rely on custom Java classes to extend the functionality of native XSLT functions, a common practice in integration projects where XSLT offered fewer built-in capabilities.  

During migration, you may encounter Java classes ranging from simple helpers (e.g., string or date transformations, counters) to more complex ones (e.g., document loaders, RFC calls, or value mapping lookups). While some advanced use cases may require redesign or alternative approaches, simpler helper classes can still be used in Cloud Integration. 

Step 1: Uploading the Java Classes 

Upload the Java classes as a JAR file and add them to the iFlow‚Äôs References (using the Archive option). 

If the java classes are contained in the same Imported Archive (IA) as the XSLT using them on PO, the migration tool will automatically import them as it imports the entire IA during the migration process. However, if the java classes are in a separate IA, this needs to be done manually post tool migration. 

Please note that the JAR file must be added as a local resource into the iFlow. Currently it‚Äôs not possible to use as a reusable artifact. 

Step 2: Adjusting XSLT Syntax 

 

  1. Namespace Declarations 

SAP Process Orchestration allows multiple styles for Java namespace declarations, while Saxon (the processor in Cloud Integration) supports only one format. 

  1. a) Inline Declaration 

xmlns:java="http://xml.apache.org/xslt/java" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform.GetDate(data)"/> 

  1. b) Namespace Declaration with Class Path 

xmlns:date="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="date:GetDate(data)"/> 

In Cloud Integration, only the second option (namespace declaration with class path) is supported. Therefore, all Java class calls must be manually adapted accordingly. 

 

  1. Type Handling in Java Class Calls 

Just like native XSLT functions, Java class calls in Cloud Integration require explicit type consistency. For example: 

<xsl:variable name="__function4" select="variable:setValue($var,'Name',string(number(data)))"/> 

If a Java class expects a string, the input must be explicitly converted. On SAP Process Orchestration, the same code might work without this conversion. 

In one specific migration case, a Java method required an integer input ‚Äî here, neither round() nor number() worked, but the XSLT function xs:integer() was necessary. 
 

Please note that compilation errors such as ‚ÄúErrors were reported during stylesheet compilation‚Äù are often related to incorrect data types. Explicitly converting inputs usually resolves these issues. 

 

References to other stylesheets within the XSLT 

XSLT code from different stylesheets can be used in an XSLT mapping using the include function: 

<xsl:include href="Stylesheet2.xsl"/> 

The included stylesheet needs to be added manually as a reference to the iflow: 

On Cloud Integration, no folder structures are supported so if the IA on PO had a nested folder structure containing the stylesheets, make sure to upload them individually and remove the path in the include function of your original stylesheet like our example above. 

 

Recommendations for Successful Migration 

To ensure smooth execution of XSLT mappings in Cloud Integration: 

  • Always verify and explicitly define correct data types. 
  • Adapt namespace declarations for all Java class calls. 
  • Adapt the include of additional stylesheets. 
  • Upload all necessary additional components (jar files, stylesheets). 
  • Test mappings individually after migration to detect type-related issues early. 
  • Simplify or refactor complex Java-dependent logic where possible. 

Following these guidelines helps prevent runtime errors and ensures stable, predictable execution after migration. 

 

Conclusion and Next Steps 

Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite requires close attention to how the underlying XSLT processor interprets data types and Java extensions. 
While most mappings migrate seamlessly, subtle differences, particularly in data type handling, namespace declarations, and custom Java integrations, may lead to compilation or runtime issues if not adjusted. 

Stay tuned for the next part of this series, where we‚Äôll continue our deep dive into migration patterns and modernization best practices in SAP Integration Suite, including insights on content-based routing, custom code handling, and error management.

entry.title: FAQ ‚Äì Migration from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog provides answers to the most frequently asked questions from customers and partners planning their migration from SAP Process Orchestration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite.

This content was prepared by many experts from different areas at SAP and it covers assessment, tooling, technical migration topics, and operational aspects to help you plan and execute a smooth transition to SAP‚Äôs cloud-native integration platform.

Last Updated: Nov 2025 ‚Äì SAP Integration Suite Move Experts.

 

Assessment and Planning

This section is focused on questions related to the initial planning or assessment of your landscape, normally before the start of the migration project.

 

Q1: Why should I move from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite?

A: Migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite enables organizations to modernize their integration landscape with a cloud-native, fully managed, and future-proof integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) that supports both cloud and hybrid scenarios.

It eliminates infrastructure maintenance, reduces total cost of ownership, and accelerates time to value through more than 4000 prebuilt integrations, 4,600+ APIs, and approx. 1400+ business events available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub (as of end of 2025) and keep adding up. See more information in Value Proposition: Why You Should Move to SAP Integration Suite.

 

Q2: What is the Migration Assessment tool in SAP Integration Suite?

A: The Migration Assessment is a capability within SAP Integration Suite designed to analyze your SAP Process Orchestration interfaces providing many insights about the interfaces‚Äô complexity, dependencies, categories of functionalities and effort estimation for the technical migration. See more information in Migration Assessment.

 

Q3: Which SAP Process Integration/Orchestration versions are supported by the Migration Assessment?

A: The Migration Assessment supports SAP Process Integration/Orchestration versions:

  • 7.31 SP28 and above
  • 7.40 SP23 and above
  • 7.50 SP06 and above

The Migration Assessment supports interfaces created based on Interface Configuration Object (ICO) and interfaces created based on Receiver Determination (together with Sender Agreement, Receiver Agreement and Interface Determination) in dual stack environments.

Note: For 7.50 (SP06 to SP09), make sure to have implemented the patch as described in the SAP Note 2456339.

 

Q4: How can I start planning my migration project?

A: Begin by running the Migration Assessment to understand your system landscape and estimate migration efforts. Then define the migration strategy (e.g., phased migration, modernization on focus areas).

Review the Migration Guide, evaluate reusable content, and prepare your SAP Integration Suite tenants (development, test, and production). SAP recommends the Discovery Center mission Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite to get confidence and understanding on the tools.

 

Q5: I have SAP Process Integration 7.1. Can I use the Migration Assessment and/or Migration Tool?

A: SAP cannot guarantee that the Migration Assessment and Migration Tool can work properly in an SAP Process Integration version different than the ones supported (see question 3), although many of the APIs used might be available on the same. SAP recommends upgrading the SAP Process Integration to a supported release before running the assessment and/or migration to ensure accurate results.

 

Q6: How can I determine the number of required message blocks while moving from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite?

A: In the Migration Assessment result, you can have the counting of message throughput and some performance indicators per interface such as the average message size, for the previous month that you ran the extraction. You can use both information to calculate the number of required messages blocks in SAP Integration Suite.

Make sure to activate the monthly performance collection on SAP Process Orchestration as per SAP Note 3300008.

For synchronous messages, you might need to check if synchronous messages are logged on the Message Overview Monitor as per the SAP Note 2442373. Make sure to read throughout the note and agree or not with any additional overhead due to the additional message logging in case this is not enabled, and you want to collect also such data.

For more information of what is the definition of a Message on SAP Integration Suite refer to the SAP Note 2942344 and Discovery Center.

 

Q7: Where can I find more information about how to use the Migration Assessment?

A: You can find more information about the Migration Assessment in the following references:

  • Use the Migration Assessment Application
  • How to use the Migration Assessment Application to get ready to migrate your SAP Process Orchestration Scenarios?

 

Q8: I have on-premise to on-premise integration scenarios and I don‚Äôt want to exchange my messages over the Internet in SAP Integration Suite. What is the best solution?

A: For on-premise to on-premise integrations where you don‚Äôt want messages to enter the public Internet, the best solution is to run your integration flows using the Edge Integration Cell. It lets you design and manage integrations in the cloud while executing all runtime processing inside your own network, fully avoiding external message exchange. You can find more information in the following references:

  • What Is Edge Integration Cell
  • Deployment Models
  • Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) on Edge Integration Cell
  • 3247839 - Prerequisites for installing SAP Integration Suite Edge Integration Cell

 

Q9. What are the typical migration approaches and how do they differ?
A: Typical migration approaches are:

  • Lift-and-Shift: Move existing SAP Process Orchestration interfaces to SAP Integration Suite with minimal functional changes. This reduces short-term project risk and effort, preserving legacy designs (quick win) and safeguarding existing investments. Use when timelines are tight or when business logic must remain unchanged. The downside is to lose the momentum to promote innovation leveraging other SAP Integration Suite capabilities than Cloud Integration.
  • Modernization: Re-design interfaces to use API-led or event-driven patterns for instance, remove deprecated technologies, consolidate redundant interfaces, centralize common functionalities and promote a Clean Core mindset. This requires more design work but yields long-term maintainability, scalability and ensures a future-proof landscape.

 

Q10. How long does a typical migration project take, and what resources are required?
A: Duration depends on landscape size, complexity, and chosen approach:

  • Small landscapes (up to 100 interfaces, mostly lift-and-shift) commonly take 1‚Äì3 months.
  • Medium landscapes (up to 300 interfaces, mostly lift-and-shift) commonly take 3-6 months.
  • Large landscapes, depending on the number of the interfaces, can take more than 1 year but also has bigger opportunities of parallelization using the right tools and promoting a learning curve across the members of the project.

Required technical resources normally include:

  1. Integration architect (for medium and large landscapes)
  2. Integration Lead
  3. Cloud Integration developers
  4. Project manager

Depending on how you want to run the validation phase, you might need to consider allocating business users for specific phases and if testing tools will be used, then specific QA/Automation Test engineers.

 

Q11. Can I run the Migration Assessment without external internet access (e.g., on secure networks)?

A: The Migration Assessment extracts data from your on-premise SAP Process Orchestration system via a secure connection established through SAP Cloud Connector to the SAP Integration Suite tenant. Because it requires a connection between the on-premise system and the SAP Integration Suite service, you cannot run the assessment entirely offline; however, connectivity is secured and routed through Cloud Connector, so your systems do not need to be open to the public internet. Please note that intermediary components such as reverse proxies cannot be used to connect with Migration Assessment.

 

Q12. Is the Migration Assessment available on all SAP Integration Suite editions (e.g., starter, standard, premium)?
A: The Migration Assessment capability is available in the Free Tier, Trial, Standard and Premium editions of SAP Integration Suite. The Migration Assessment is not available in SAP Cloud Integration (Neo environment).

 

Q13. Can AI tools assist in modernization (e.g., auto-mapping, code transformation)?
A: Yes. SAP Integration Suite leverages AI-assisted capabilities to support and accelerate modernization. these include:

  • Generative AI for flow generation: You can bootstrap Integration Flows using AI, helping to create integration flows more quickly.
  • Integration Advisor enhancements: AI can suggest mapping patterns and recommend semantic mappings based on libraries and historical data.
  • Anomaly detection: AI helps detect runtime anomalies and integration issues, enabling proactive monitoring and optimization.
  • AI-powered adapter: There is an AI Adapter for Integration Suite that facilitates generative AI‚Äìdriven integration scenarios.

These AI features can reduce manual effort, speed up design, and improve the quality of migrated or modernized integrations. See more information in Artificial Intelligence.

 

Q14. How does modernization differ from migration?
A: Migration is the technical move of integration artifacts from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite with the minimum changes to make the interface runnable again. Modernization is a broader redesign that rethinks integration patterns (e.g., APIs/events, pipelines), removes obsolete constructs, and aligns integrations with cloud-native practices. It often follows or accompanies migration but has a stronger emphasis on long-term architecture, reusability, and business enablement.

 

Q15: Where can I find more information about modernization?

A: You can find more information about modernization in the following references:

  • Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles
  • Modernization Recommendations
  • Modernizing RFC/BAPI-based Integrations for a Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite
  • Modernizing for a Clean Core: IDoc to Events & APIs in SAP PI/PO to Integration Suite Migration
  • Modernize RFC Sender Communications into API-Based protocols in Cloud Integration
  • Modernize RFC Receiver Communications into API-Based Protocols in Cloud Integration

 

Migration Tools and Capabilities

This section is focused on questions related to the tooling available to automate and accelerate your migration from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite.

 

Q1: Is there a tool to migrate my interfaces from SAP Process Orchestration?

A: Yes. The Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite accelerates the conversion of SAP Process Orchestration integration artifacts (e.g., mappings, communication channels, and interface objects) into Cloud Integration artifacts. It significantly reduces manual effort and ensures consistency between the source and target environments. See more information in Migration Tooling.

 

Q2: What are the benefits of using the Migration Tool in Cloud Integration?

A: The Migration Tool accelerates the migration process, minimizes manual effort, and reduces human errors. The Migration Tool helps to ensure that the developer reuses common artifacts and that the interfaces are migrated in a consistent way.

 

Q3: Are there any limitations in the Migration Tool?

A: Yes. The Migration Tool currently supports a defined set of adapters, components and integration patterns. Some complex scenarios (e.g., BPM, ccBPM, custom adapter modules, mappings with unsupported functions) may require manual adjustment. See more information in Known Limitations of Migration Tooling. Please note that the Migration Tool is continuously updated to close the gaps and to increase scenario coverage.

 

Q4: Is there a way to import SAP Process Orchestration artifacts without using the Migration Tool?

A: Yes. The Migration Tool will take care to import the dependent objects from your interface all at once; however, if you prefer, you can import many artifacts in an isolated manner. See more information in the following references:

  • Service Interface
  • Function Library
  • Imported Archive
  • WSDL
  • Value Mapping
  • Data Type and Message Type
  • Operation Mapping

 

Q5: Is Cloud Connector setup mandatory to connect the Migration Assessment and Migration Tool to SAP Process Orchestration?

A: Yes. The SAP Cloud Connector is required to establish a secure connection between SAP Integration Suite (cloud) and the on-premise SAP Process Orchestration system. It allows the tools to extract configuration data without exposing the system directly to the internet. See more in Add an SAP Process Orchestration System.

 

Q6: Does the Migration Tool support other non-SAP integration platforms?

A: No. The Migration Tool is designed specifically for migrating integration scenarios from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite. Migration from non-SAP platforms must be handled manually or with partner tools specialized in cross-platform migrations.

 

Q7: Where can I find more information about the Migration Tool?

A: You can find more information about the Migration Tool in the following references:

  • What Is Migration Tooling?
  • Use the Migration Tooling
  • SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance
  • Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite

 

Q8. How are the Message Mappings migrated with the Migration Tool?
A: The Migration Tool analyzes message mappings and imports them into Cloud Integration as the best available equivalent: it will convert native message mapping objects where possible, importing Message Mapping as local or global resources. The migration wizard supports reuse where possible (for example, reusing existing message mapping artifacts as shared resources).

Note: XSLT and Java mappings are only imported as local resources.

 

Q9. Is the Migration Tool available on all SAP Integration Suite editions (e.g., starter, standard, premium)?
A: The Migration Tool is a feature of the Cloud Integration capability on SAP Integration Suite and is generally available in the Free Tier, Trial, Standard and Premium editions of SAP Integration Suite. The Migration Tool is not available in SAP Cloud Integration (Neo environment).

 

Q10. How are security credentials handled during migration (e.g., user/passwords, keystores)?
A: Credentials and keystore material are not automatically migrated. The Migration Tool will migrate some connectivity/credential references (i.e., adapter parameters, keystore aliases, user IDs), but you must reconfigure and securely store credentials in the SAP Integration Suite tenant (e.g., Key Store, OAuth credentials). Keystores and certificates can be manually exported/imported and must be validated for post-migration. Treat credentials separately in your runbook and ensure secure handling (do not embed plain passwords in migrated flows). See more information in Managing Security Material in Cloud Integration.

 

Functional and Technical Migration Topics

This section is focused on questions related to specific use cases while migrating interfaces from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, its differences and migration strategy.

 

Q1: Is it possible to reuse Operation Mappings from SAP Process Orchestration in Cloud Integration?

A: Yes, you can import the Operation Mappings from the ES Repository to Cloud Integration. However, since you cannot edit the Operation Mapping after the import, SAP recommends importing the individual steps of your Operation Mapping as flow steps (i.e., Message Mappings, XSLT, Java Mappings). The Migration Tool is able to read the content of the Operation Mapping whereas the Operation Mapping as such won‚Äôt be imported, instead all referenced artifacts such as message mappings, XSLTs, and Java mappings will be imported following SAP‚Äôs recommendation.

 

Q2: What happens with my ABAP Proxies in ECC or SAP S/4HANA post-migration?

A: ABAP Proxies can still be generated in design and used in runtime, but instead of connecting to SAP Process Orchestration, they will connect to SAP Integration Suite. For more information how to migrate the ABAP proxy for the design and runtime, see the following references:

  • ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite (Design)
  • Migrating SAP PI/PO XI Proxy scenarios to Integration Suite ‚Äì Key considerations and recommendations (Design)
  • Setting Up XI Proxy Runtime (Runtime)

For the runtime, to avoid having one SM59 destination per Integration Flow, you can create an Integration Flow with an XI sender adapter acting as a single XI entry point and which then dispatches the XI messages to the actual integration flows. SAP recommends using the Pipeline for Cloud Integration which supports this approach out of the box via a so-called generic XI inbound processing flow. Furthermore, to handle XI messages sent from Cloud Integration to an ECC or SAP S/4HANA system in a common way, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration supports a generic XI outbound processing flow also taking e.g. message packaging into account.

The Pipeline for Cloud Integration actually supports the runtime of any interface in SAP Integration Suite by recreating the SAP Process Integration/Orchestration-style pipeline execution using a set of generic, reusable integration flows that handle receiver determination, interface determination, mapping, routing, and retries, allowing messages to run through a structured, processing sequence. See more information in Pipeline Concept and in particular section Generic Inbound and Outbound.

 

Q3: What happens with my IDocs in ECC or SAP S/4HANA post-migration?

A: IDoc-based communication can continue through Cloud Integration using the IDoc adapter. The connection between ECC or SAP S/4HANA and the SAP Integration Suite tenant can be established securely via Cloud Connector or Direct Connection depending on your network setup. See more information in IDoc Adapter.

For the runtime, SAP also recommends using the Pipeline for Cloud Integration. Like for XI inbound and XI outbound, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration comes with a generic IDoc inbound processing flow as well as a generic IDoc outbound processing flow to handle the configuration of IDoc scenarios in a common way (see previous question). See more information in Pipeline Concept and in particular section Generic Inbound and Outbound.

 

Q4: How can I migrate my adapter modules (standard and custom)?

A: Standard and custom adapter modules may already have equivalent functionality in Cloud Integration through pre-built adapter features or out-of-the-box flow steps. In case they are not available, you can check as well the Message Transformation Utilities community package, where you can also find many of these adapter modules converted into Groovy scripts and ready to use. See more information in Adapter Modules in the Migration Guide.

 

Q5: How can I migrate my Java Mappings?

A: The Migration Tool will import your Java Mapping as a non-editable local resource (.JAR) to your Integration Flow and will wrap the mapping call using a Groovy script as per defined in Migration Java Mappings. Please be aware that your Java Mapping will only work if it‚Äôs not using any SAP Process Orchestration specific library. SAP recommends converting the Java Mapping to Groovy if possible, however, adapting the Java code and recompiling it using an external IDE is also an option for small adjustments.

The Migration Tool will not import additional dependencies, so you need to import them manually post-migration.

 

Q6: How to handle PGP Encryption/Decryption while moving from SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration?

A: The Migration Tool supports the migration of the standard adapter modules for PGP Encryption/Decryption. That means that by post-migration you‚Äôll be able to see the Encryptor or Decryptor flow steps. The PGP keys must be manually imported into Cloud Integration.

 

Q7: Are RFC/JDBC lookups supported in Cloud Integration?

A: Yes, but with some differences. RFC lookups can be achieved via RFC adapter or OData/API-based service calls. JDBC lookups are supported through the JDBC adapter, provided the database is securely reachable from the cloud via Cloud Connector. See more in RFC Lookup and JDBC Lookup tutorials.
In SAP Process Integration/Orchestration the lookup was often done directly in the mapping using a reference to a Communication Channel. In Cloud Integration, you can decide if you want to implement the lookup directly as a UDF or in a separated step. By doing in a separated step outside the mapping, you also simplify the monitoring.

 

Q8: Is it possible to reuse Function Libraries in Cloud Integration?

A: Yes. Function Libraries (FL) can be imported into Cloud Integration. You can import them together with your interface using the Migration Tool or import specific Function Libraries directly into a package. This allows you to bring Function Library definitions into Cloud Integration and reuse them across Integration Flows. However, you should review any library references and adjust naming conventions or package structures to ensure they work correctly in your migrated interfaces.

 

Q9: How to move from SAP Process Orchestration B2B Toolkit to SAP Integration Suite?

A: You can migrate B2B scenarios from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite by following the dedicated B2B migration guidance. The recommended approach is to first assess existing B2B components (agreements, mappings, message types) and then select one of the supported migration paths:

  • Migrate to Cloud Integration, converting ICOs, mappings, and B2B message flows into Integration Flows using the migration approaches and templates provided.
  • Adopt Trading Partner Management (TPM), which replaces PO‚Äôs B2B Toolkit by managing partners, agreements, and message processing natively in Integration Suite.

During migration, you may need to adjust adapters, communication channels, and partner-specific configurations. For instance, as of today, EDISeparator can‚Äôt be migrated and imply into a redesign of your B2B interface.

After migration, re-create or refine partner setups in TPM or Cloud Integration and validate end-to-end B2B processing before go-live. See more information in Migrating B2B Interfaces.

For more questions how to proceed with your B2B migration journey, please contact the b2bintegrationfactory@sap.com, which is a focused team at SAP to support customers on the B2B migration.

 

Q10: Does SAP Integration Suite support transport mechanisms comparable to those in SAP Process Orchestration?

A: Yes. SAP Integration Suite supports artifact transport using Cloud Transport Management Service (CTMS). See more information in Transport Management Options.

 

Q11: Is there any testing automation tool to validate my interfaces post-migration?

A: Yes. SAP recommends partner tools like INT4 IFTT or Figaf Testing Suite for automated validation. These tools help compare source and target message payloads, mappings, and end-to-end message flows. See more information in Int4 Shield Lite or Figaf DevOps.

 

Q12: How can I migrate my ccBPM or BPM from SAP Process Integration/Orchestration to Cloud Integration?

A: Cloud Integration does not support the migration of ccBPM or BPM directly, although you can redesign them into normal Integration Flows using the processes flow steps as they are based on BPMN. For integration-centric processes, see Guidelines to Implement Specific Integration Patterns. For human-centric workflows, use SAP Build Process Automation.

 

Q13: Are there best practices for structuring and naming artifacts in Cloud Integration?

A: Yes. Use consistent naming conventions that reflect integration purpose, source, and target systems. Group related artifacts within packages. See more information in Naming Conventions.

 

Q14: How to ensure Quality of Service (Exactly Once and Exactly Once In Order) support in Cloud Integration?

A: Cloud Integration supports Exactly Once (EO) and Exactly Once In Order (EOIO) through JMS queues. Additionally, idempotent handling is required which, unlike in SAP Process Integration/Orchestration, is often not built into the adapter itself but must be modelled directly in the Integration Flow. See more in Quality of Service.
Usage of JMS queues requires a concept for efficient operations to e.g. model restarts in case of errors, error notification and error handling. Also, the number of JMS queues in a tenant is limited and should therefore be used carefully. More information about the JMS queues in Cloud Integration can be found in Cloud Integration - JMS Resource and Size Limits.
Also in this case, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration offers the usage of generic queues and implements generic error handling and restart options.

 

Q15: Is there a way to prioritize selected integration scenarios in Cloud Integration?

A: Prioritization can be managed by configuring separate JMS queues. This ensures that high-priority scenarios receive processing preference and are not delayed by bulk traffic. You can also apply pipeline designs that route high-priority messages to specific queues. When using the Pipeline for Cloud Integration, you can setup multiple pipelines and configure the JMS sender adapters of each pipeline accordingly to assign more tenant resources for high priority scenarios.

 

Q16: How can I check which standard content is available in SAP Integration Suite to replace my standard XI content?

A: You can explore the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, which contains over 10,000 prepackaged integrations, APIs, events, etc. Use it to identify equivalent or improved content that can replace standard XI Content from SAP Process Orchestration.

 

Q17: Can I test my mappings and messages directly in Cloud Integration like in SAP Process Orchestration?

A: Yes. There are two possibilities to test mappings and messages in Cloud Integration. You can either test only your message mapping in the editor page, or you can run your Integration Flow in a simulation where you can validate one or more flow steps, including your message mappings. You can monitor payloads and headers for validation before deployment. See more in Test Message Mapping and Simulation of an Integration Flow.

 

Q18: Will User-Defined Functions (UDFs) be converted to Groovy scripts after migration using the Migration Tool?

A: No. The Migration Tool does not automatically convert UDFs into Groovy scripts. UDFs can be imported and may continue to work as-is if they do not depend on PI/PO-specific libraries; if they do, you must refactor them manually (convert to Groovy or adapt Java code). Track UDFs during assessment and plan manual conversion as needed.

 

Q19: Can I migrate interfaces with adapters that are not available in Cloud Integration?

A: The Migration Tool does not automatically migrate such adapters, although you may migrate parts of the interface and apply the necessary adaptations after the migration. These adaptations might include:

  1. Replace the adapters to more generic protocols (e.g., HTTPS) and implement specific requirements using flow steps.
  2. If it‚Äôs a partner adapter, check with the same provider if they have a replacement for Cloud Integration.
  3. As a last resource, you can create your custom adapter using ADK. See more information in Developing Custom Adapters.

 

Q20: Which Java version can I use for dependencies in Groovy Script?

A: Make sure to follow the code guidelines for Java 17. See more information in the SAP Note 3498280 - Script incompatibilities with upcoming software upgrade.

 

Q21: Can I use my own CI/CD pipeline to manage my Cloud Integration artifacts?

A: Yes. Cloud Integration exposes APIs (Cloud Integration OData/REST) that allow export/import and automation of artifacts; you can integrate these into your CI/CD pipelines (Git + build pipelines + deploy scripts). For more information about the Cloud Integration APIs, access Business Accelerator Hub.

Please find below few additional community and partners references to create or use CI/CD pipelines on Cloud Integration:

  • CI/CD for SAP Integration Suite? Here you go!
  • SAP CPI: CI/CD from from zero to hero
  • FlashPipe: The CI/CD Companion for SAP Integration Suite
  • Figaf DevOps Suite for SAP

 

Q22. How do I migrate interfaces with ‚ÄúAdapter-Specific Message Attributes‚Äù (Dynamic Configuration)?
A: Adapter-specific attributes (dynamic configuration) become message headers or properties in Cloud Integration. Map adapter attributes to message headers/parameters to preserve behavior. Review and test each adapter configuration since attribute names and behaviors may differ between SAP Process Orchestration and Cloud Integration. See more information in Headers and Exchange Properties Provided by the Integration Framework.
If you are using Dynamic configurations in your Mappings you need to adjust them accordingly by also accessing these headers within your Mapping. If you are reading such headers and properties, you can use the in-built node functions, if you need to change such values, please proceed with Groovy script as explained in Access Headers and Properties in Scripts.

 

Q23. Can I reuse my configuration from Integration Directory (e.g., Receiver Determination, Interface Determination)?

A: Yes, you can reuse the logical design by migrating your configuration to Cloud Integration using the Pipeline for Cloud Integration that emulates Receiver/Interface Determination. The Migration Tool supports the Pipeline Approach which assists you in creating integration artifacts such as integration flows, mappings and Partner Directory entries to run your scenarios in the Pipeline for Cloud Integration. See more information in Pipeline Approach. Optionally, you can manually create the artifacts. In this case, use the so-called Partner Directory Accelerator Tool provided by the community.


Q24. Are synchronous/asynchronous bridges supported (sync-async or async-sync patterns)?
A: Async-sync pattern is supported in a manual migration and using Migration Tool.

The opposite sync-async pattern, where a synchronous request is converted into an asynchronous message and the Integration Flow waits for the asynchronous response from the target API within a single integration flow is not supported as of today.

 

Q25. How can I migrate Alerts Rules or notification integration scenarios?
A: You cannot migrate Alert Rules from SAP Process Orchestration as-is. However, SAP recommends reconfiguring such alerts using SAP Cloud ALM. See more information in Alerting. Alternatively, you can also use the SAP Alert Notification Service for SAP BTP.

 

Q26. How can I migrate Message Mapping with Value Mapping-lookups?

A: Value Mappings are supported and can be migrated as Value Mapping objects into Cloud Integration. The Migration Tool imports value mappings references in the message mapping, but it does not migrate the Value Mapping object itself. After migrating the interface, you can import the Value Mapping directly into the package and validate whether the values are correct.

Q27. How can I migrate my ValueMappingReplication and ValueMappingReplicationSynchronous scenarios?

A: These scenarios can‚Äôt be directly migrated to Cloud Integration. Value Mappings are separate artifacts in Cloud Integration and they can updated via OData API calls and not via a standard interface. Note that updates via API are only for the design time versions of the Value Mappings, they still need to be deployed to the runtime to reflect the changes. Refer to blog Migrating ValueMappingReplication from SAP PI/PO to CPI on step-by-step instructions.


Q28: Is it possible to use dynamic EOIO queues in Cloud Integration?

A: In dynamic EOIO queues, the queue name is set based on payload information or using custom adapter modules. As of today, dynamic queues are not supported directly on Cloud Integration as the name of a JMS queues must be fixed. A possible option is to use a shared queue but in case of errors messages could block each other. If you require same setup as of today, please look at following roadmap item in the SAP Integration Suite Roadmap.

 

Q29: Is it possible to archive messages in Cloud Integration

A: If you require message archiving in Cloud Integration, this is possible using an external Content Management System (CMS). For more information check the online help and have a look at SAP Note 3449326

Q30: Is Time Availability Planning supported in Cloud Integration:

A: In SAP Process Orchestration you could use time availability planning to stop a Communication Channel at a specific time. In SAP Cloud Integration you might use a timer event for adapters that support request/reply pattern to achieve similar functionality. Alternatively, you can implement your own mechanism to temporarily stop receiving messages for a defined period, as demonstrated in the blog Add SAP PI/PO Communication Channel Start/Stop Functionality to Your iFlows.  

Please note that using a timer event with request/reply pattern might have an impact on the message consumption, considering that each message execution will count as at least one transaction. For more information about the message metric definition, see on SAP Note 2942344.

 

Security and Connectivity

This section is focused on questions related to security use cases and connectivity differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite.

 

Q1. How is authentication and authorization handled in SAP Integration Suite?
A: SAP Integration Suite uses the identity and access management (IAM) features of SAP BTP / SAP Cloud Identity Services to handle authentication and authorization. Key points:

  • Identity Authentication (IAS): Users (both developers and business users) are authenticated via SAP Identity Authentication Service or a trusted external identity provider. See more information in Security Administration: Managing Authentication and Authorization.
    • SAP has its own SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant, SAP ID service. SAP ID service is the default identity provider of SAP BTP and where you register to get initial access to SAP BTP. Trust to SAP ID service is preconfigured by default.
  • Roles & Role Collections: Authorization is managed through role collections in BTP. Administrators assign predefined role collections (e.g., for Cloud Integration personas) to users or groups to control what they can do. See more information in Personas for Cloud Integration.
  • Service Authentication (OAuth / Service Keys): For system-to-system communication, Integration Suite supports OAuth 2.0 client credentials flows. You can create a service instance with a service key to obtain OAuth credentials (client ID / secret) for integration scenarios. See more information in Creating Service Instance and Service Key for Inbound Authentication.
  • Certificate-based Authentication: If you configure client certificate authentication, the load balancer (or relevant component) validates the certificate and maps it to a service key for Integration Suite. See more information in Client Certificate Authentication (Inbound).

This layered IAM model ensures both human user access and secure service-to-service authentication, using OAuth, certificates, and strong role-based control.

 

Q2. How do I handle certificates and keystores after migration?
A: Certificates, private keys, and keystores from SAP Process Orchestration are not migrated automatically and must be uploaded manually into the Cloud Integration Keystore. During migration, you should export certificates from SAP Process Orchestration, import them into the tenant, and reassign them to the respective adapters or endpoints. Renewal must also be managed manually using the tenant‚Äôs keystore tools. See more information in Managing Security Material in Cloud Integration and Managing Keystore Entries.

 

Q3. Can SAP Integration Suite connect to on-premise systems without VPN?
A: Yes. Integration Suite can connect to on-premise systems without requiring a VPN by using the SAP Cloud Connector, which establishes a secure reverse-proxy tunnel from on-premise to BTP. This avoids opening inbound firewall ports. See more information in Connecting to On-Premise Systems Using Cloud Connector.

Alternatively, SAP Private Link Service can also be used to establish private, non-internet network connectivity between BTP and hyperscaler VPC/VNet environments. However, as of today you cannot connect SAP Integration Suite to the SAP Private Link Service. You would rather need an app router deployed also in BTP to intermediate the message exchanges. Please make sure to check if the required service for your scenario is supported while using SAP Private Link Service and also any potential limitation that might exist. SAP also recommends running a Proof of Concept first while using this approach. See more information in What Is SAP Private Link Service? And SAP Private Link Service Use Cases for SAP Cloud Integration.

 

Monitoring and Operations

This section is focused on questions related to monitoring, logging, archiving and operation related differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite.

 

Q1: How should error handling and logging be adapted in SAP Integration Suite?

A: SAP Integration Suite provides modern, cloud-based error handling and logging capabilities. Use exception subprocesses, audit logs, and message tracing to design resilient error management. See more information in Guidelines and Best Practices for Message Monitoring.

 

Q2: Can I reprocess failed messages in SAP Integration Suite like in SAP Process Orchestration?

A: Unlike SAP Process Orchestration, SAP Integration Suite does not have a ‚Äúrestart message‚Äù feature built in. However, you can implement the retry mechanism using JMS queues. See more information in Apply the Retry Pattern.
The Pipeline for Cloud Integration supports built-in error handling and restart capabilities, i.e., automatic retries as well as manual retry options including a so-called dead letter queue where messages are stored which have exceeded the maximum number of retries. Furthermore, you have the option to use an extension package which supports sophisticated restart capabilities using data store instead of the standard error handling provided by the pipeline. See Process Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store.

 

Q3: How can we get alerts for failed integrations in SAP Integration Suite?

A: You can configure SAP Cloud ALM to receive alerts based on message status. Cloud ALM provides dashboards, notification rules, and APIs for monitoring Integration Suite message health and exceptions. See more information in SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration) and Alerting.

Alternatively, you can also use the SAP Alert Notification Service for SAP BTP.

 

Q4: How to migrate User-Defined Message Search when moving from SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration?

A: A User-Defined Message Search configuration cannot be directly migrated. However, you can replicate similar functionality by defining custom message attributes in Cloud Integration, which can be used for filtering and searching in Message Monitoring. See: Custom Header Properties to Search for Message Processing Logs.

 

Q5: Is it possible to monitor channels migrated to Cloud Integration?

A: Cloud Integration does not use ‚Äúcommunication channels‚Äù as in SAP Process Orchestration. Instead, message flows are monitored via the Message Monitoring view, which provides detailed visibility of message status, runtime logs, and performance. See more information in Monitor Message Processing.

 

Q6: Can I reuse my SLD settings (business systems, technical systems, SWCV, etc.) in Cloud Integration?
